title: What are microplastics? - NOAA's National Ocean Service
body: Plastic is the most prevalent type of marine debris found in our ocean and Great Lakes. Plastic debris can come in all shapes and sizes, but those that are less than five millimeters in length (or about the size of a sesame seed) are called "microplastics.". user (2023-12-08): An official website of the United States government provides information about microplastics on the National Ocean Service page. The article explains that microplastics are small plastic pieces less than five millimeters long which can be harmful to the ocean and aquatic life. It also discusses the sources of microplastics, including larger plastic debris that degrades into smaller pieces and microbeads used in health and beauty products. The website also mentions the banning of plastic microbeads in cosmetics and personal care products in 2015.

- It is essential to raise awareness about microplastics and their potential impact on the environment, and to promote initiatives for reducing plastic use and waste.
